body: Karen Hubert Allison, who with her husband, Len Allison, lived out every cook's fantasy of turning a home into a restaurant and later earned three stars for the establishment, Huberts, in Manhattan, died on Tuesday in Maui, Hawaii. She was 49 and had lived in Maui since 1995. The cause of death was breast cancer, said Dr. Wayne Lavender, a family
title: Karen Allison, 49, Restaurateur With Vision

body: A T-SHIRT seen the other day summed it up. ''Welcome to New York,'' it said. ''Now go home.'' Stephen Sheppard's sentiments exactly. Mr. Sheppard is a lawyer with an office on West 57th Street near Fifth Avenue, an area where out-of-towners are thicker than yuppies in a cigar store. ''You can't get there from here,'' he said, describing his recent
title: NYC ; Isn't It Time For You To Leave?

body: A black man who had stopped to use a pay phone in Brooklyn early yesterday morning was attacked by three white teen-agers while a friend stood by helplessly, the police said. The incident was being investigated as a bias crime because the suspects yelled racial slurs at the victim while beating him with a baseball bat and a clublike car anti-theft
title: 3 Accused of Beating Black Man in Suspected Bias Crime

body: BRAWTA CARIBBEAN CAFE ++ (718) 855-5515; 347 Atlantic Avenue (Hoyt Street), Boerum Hill; $; all major credit cards. Among the highlights are the chicken roti, or large flatbread made with crushed chickpeas and rolled
title: Brooklyn's New Or Tried and True

body: A school crossing guard was critically injured in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn yesterday morning when a police tow truck ran a red light and hit another car, which struck the guard, the police said. The crossing guard, Roseann Laface, 49, was waiting at 8:25 A.M. near Public School 29 to guide children to the safety of a sidewalk. To the
title: School Crossing Guard Is Hit In Crash Involving City Truck

body: IF there was one thing that New York City's community school boards could count on over the last quarter century -- if there was one constant that defined the realpolitik of education on the neighborhood level -- it was this: the school boards got to pick the principals. So it was no surprise when a school board member went to meet with the new
title: District Superintendents Are Supposed to Change the Public Schools. Can They?

body: WHEN they bought their Boerum Hill house in 1987, it needed just about everything: plumbing, electrical wiring, all new moldings. And like all first-time old-house buyers, they vowed to do most of the work themselves. ''I stripped the whole staircase,'' said Lulee Williams. ''Seven surgeries later -- yes, as a result I had repetitive stress injury;
title: Veterans of a Fixer-Upper Are Taking On Another

body: To the Editor: I was excited to read of Michel Marriott's solution to the problem of how to fit in movies when you have an infant: seeing segments of films during his lunch hour (Coping, ''Alone in the Dark,'' Aug. 10). Barbara and I, too, have seen only three films since our son Eli was born 10 months ago. What I miss is not the films so much as
title: Lunchtime Moviegoing Can Be Parallel Experience

body: ASENCIO-Maria. 9/6/39 to 8/6/97. Passed away Wednesday. Loving and devoted wife to Alfredo. Proud and adoring mother to Arlene, Deborah and Paul. Doting grandmother to Conor and Nina. She will be remembered for her generous spirit, caring soul and her love of laughter. Wake at Cobble Hill Chapels, 171 Court Street, Brooklyn, 2-5 and 7-10, Saturday
title: Paid Notice: Deaths ASENCIO, MARIA

body: The 600 nurses at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn have postponed a strike that was to begin at 7 A.M. today. The union delayed the strike because it had expected to resume negotiations at a meeting on Monday with a Federal mediator. But hospital officials did not show up for the meeting. ''This is clearly part of their stand, which is
title: Nurses' Strike Is Delayed in Hope of New Talks

body: When Sandy Miller and his sister, Madeline Kane, founded their publishing company 12 years ago, they were determined not to ''add to the amount of dross'' in children's literature. title: Adults, Too, Like 2 Children's Books About Digestion

title: On Atlantic Avenue, Another Boom, at Least in Optimism

body: School investigators charged a 41-year-old Brooklyn music teacher yesterday with sexually abusing a 13-year-old female student in his locked classroom last month, and they criticized the school's principal for failing to reassign the teacher after learning of the allegations. It was the second case in a week in which officials said that
title: Brooklyn Teacher Held in Sex Abuse of Student, 13

body: ROSSELL-Rafael. Passed away unexpectedly Sunday, May 11, 1997, of heart failure. Beloved husband of Ana. Father of Roxana, Robert and Roman. Grandfather of Jocelyn. A dedicated father, psychoanalyst, critical intellectual and educator throughout his life. His family, friends, colleagues and students will miss his wit, insight and sensitivity.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths ROSSELL, RAFAEL

body: A teacher's aide was arrested yesterday and charged with sexually abusing a 14-year-old male student in a teacher's lounge at a Brooklyn intermediate school. A teacher who entered the locked lounge at Intermediate School 293 in Cobble Hill on April 30 discovered Antonio Perez, 56, with the eighth grader, who told the teacher that Mr. Perez had just
title: Teacher's Aide Faces Sexual Abuse Charges

body: THEY glisten, boiled bright red, heaps and heaps of spiced whole crawfish spread across a dinner table deep in the heart of Cajun country. It's a weeknight at Dwight Landreneau's house, not a weekend, but zydeco music fills the room, and someone has popped open a beer. Only in crawfish season is such a feast possible. ''This is the best time of
title: Crawfish Wars: Cajun Country Vs. China

body: CUCINA ** $(rating: two stars$) (718) 230-0711; 256 Fifth Avenue (Garfield Place), Park Slope; $$; American Express, Mastercard, Visa A painted tin ceiling, sunny mural and antique wood serving tables contribute to the rustic Tuscan feel at this friendly neighborhood favorite. The engaging Italian cooking at reasonable prices completes the picture.
title: Congenial Settings Around Brooklyn

body: CONFRONTED with some of the most pressing problems of public education, city school officials in recent years have turned to community groups to help resuscitate failing schools, teach music and arts, and rehabilitate the most troubled youngsters. But the efforts of two community groups to seize the initiative and create new schools in Brooklyn and
title: Hard Lessons in Creating a School

body: IN her novel ''Pretty Girls'' (Crown Publishers, 1988), Garret Weyr described a group of friends who called themselves the Amazon Club, three tall strong-minded young women with terrible love lives. Ms. Weyr, 32, could have been one of them. She is 5 feet 11 inches tall, with red curly hair and a tendency, she said, to dominate conversations. Until
title: Jeffrey Freymann and Garret Weyr

body: Late last fall, a pivotal piece of school legislation hung in the balance, a bill to greatly increase the power of the New York City Schools Chancellor. title: Harry Spence Clears Paths For the Schools Chancellor

body: The term comfort food has earned a pedestal in cliche heaven over the last 10 years, but that has not made the nurturing, unthreatening dishes embraced by the term any less popular. Nor has it discouraged restaurants from endless offerings of meatloaf, roast chicken, salmon and steak. Can you chew mashed potatoes and yawn at the same time? It
title: $25 and Under

body: This time, almost no one erupted in ecstatic cheers or gasped in stunned dismay. This time, almost no one seemed surprised. Many New Yorkers, in fact, were not even paying attention when the verdict in O. J. Simpson's civil trial was unveiled last night. After all, the Knicks were playing the Houston Rockets. And President Clinton had just finished
title: In New York, Many People Anticipated The Verdict

body: As housing prices in Manhattan continue to climb, the Brooklyn town house market has started to soar, not only in Brooklyn Heights but also in nearby Cobble Hill, where houses are starting to sell for more than $1 million, a record for the neighborhood. At the same time, the number of houses being sold has also shot up, with one broker saying his
title: In Brooklyn Neighborhoods, Market for Town Houses Soars
